title: Catch2 application header not always displayed
body:
**Description**
The application header (including relevant info such as Catch2 version and random seed) is only printed when some tests fail or when forcing the inclusion of successful tests in the output.


**Expected behavior**
The application header, ie
```
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
a.out is a Catch v2.11.0 host application.
Run with -? for options
```
should always be shown, regardless of the results of the tests. Ideally, the application header would be shown immediately after starting the application. 


**Reproduction steps**
Consider the following test file `foo.cpp`:
```
#define CATCH_CONFIG_MAIN

#include <catch2/catch.hpp>

TEST_CASE("LOL")
{
    CHECK(1==1);
}

TEST_CASE("LAL")
{
    CHECK(1==1);
}
```

The application header is shown only when tests fail or when using `-s`:

```
$ g++ foo.cpp
$ ./a.out 
===============================================================================
All tests passed (2 assertions in 2 test cases)

$ ./a.out -s

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
a.out is a Catch v2.11.0 host application.
Run with -? for options

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
LOL
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
foo.cpp:5
...............................................................................

foo.cpp:7: PASSED:
  CHECK( 1==1 )
with expansion:
  1 == 1

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
LAL
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
foo.cpp:10
...............................................................................

foo.cpp:12: PASSED:
  CHECK( 1==1 )
with expansion:
  1 == 1

===============================================================================
All tests passed (2 assertions in 2 test cases)

```
